title: Ate my battery.
comment: Would like to support this,  but it won't lie down. Once I saw it was using literally half my battery, I uninstalled it. If the development team come up with a way to keep it inactive or make it more obvious if that way exists, I'll gladly keep it for a rainy day.

title: Great app
comment: ... but it's out of date on your website and on F-Droid. (And I'm not sure it's still being worked on)

title: Excellent idea
comment: This is a great idea, and my phone is rooted so it works. Problem is finding others that are willing or able to root their phones. Wish creating an adhoc network didn't require this. Using a wifi router works, but using hotspot network sorta does although  sometimes one caller can't hear the other.

title: So much potential ,so much work to do
comment: This is a great concept and had so much potential ... There are certain bugs and I would be more than happy to to help you guys out in any way possible ...

title: I would love to have no root

title: Does it really works??
comment: I gave it 5 star....bcoz i know about mesh networking....i have not used the app yet....but i take guarantee that it will run well.....thnx developer...the future of communication is here...i would suggest you to improve its ui...size is nt been the issue.:-)(can i get source code plz?!)

title: Brilliant Concept
comment: If this app did not require the device to be rooted the number of nodes could increase greatly.

title: Not fully functional without root
comment: Nice idea, maybe, but you can't get an ad hoc WiFi mesh network unless you have root access, and this app requires extensive permissions to work.

title: Great app, better the Firechat
comment: This is the best app to get for emergencies or for use anytime when you need it.   1. It  does not require you to create an account to use which does require an internet connection so it is useless if installed after the net goes down and there is no reason to make an account for something that supposed to be used when there is no service as Firechat does.  2. You can share the app directly with another person you chat with and do not require to be on the internet or have cell service allowing others to install and use the app should the need arise.  It is all and all the best app I have used so far.

title: Help
comment: This is really great app I love the concept ... I live in Yemen and there is war ...communication services started to turn off... i hope it help us over here

title: Cock blocks my wifi (turns it off every 3 minutes)

title: Very cool
comment: Seems rough around the edges a bit, but was able to set up my own 2 peer network with a nexus 4 & a 5, using one as the wifi hotspot, and free of any other connections! Made calls well, with even less lag than when over my regular wifi network. The range extenders would be handy, but even a   This will be very handy! Hope you guys keep developing it! The whole over all concept is amazing!

Glastonbury Festival, where 1/4 million extra people arrive by a small village, is the worst I have attended.

title: I Used it. It worked Moto Razr with Moto G
comment: I tried to use it a couple of times before. But it worked this time. Its a brilliant concept. Do let me know if I can be of any help. The only problem was that there was a delay in relay of voice call from the host to the receiver. The Receiver's voice had a huge delay of more than 30 sec. Also, the broadcast message kept popping up. There wasn't any option to delete or mark as read. Great work! Cheers Sid

title: Rockin'
comment: On my rooted Gio, Serval rocks the house. If you ever used the Bonjour IM protocol, Serval should be a snap. Works on networks like a forban client and provides decent SIP on top.  For fast and simple communication, give Sercal a shot.  Oh, yeah. I sould mention we once used tehe 0.8 versions.   Another thing: if you are going camping, hack a Serval Mesh Helper together. Effective range phone2phone is about a hundred yards tops. With the extender, you can go waaaay further. As in ~1km.

The Android community owes it to itself to support this project.  The Serval Mesh is to the Android community and "the providers" as the electric car was to the auto industry and big oil.

title: Application runs, but Need a Walkthrough
comment: There's a bit confusion where I'm at as to how this program is supposed to work. My friend and I have it installed, however we are unable to send messages to each other. None of us have rooted phones. I think a good walkthrough would be perfect.  We're both engineers and we're still not able to get it to work. Great idea, but we'll see. If developers want to contact me, that would be useful too.

title: Ed
comment: This is one of the most cutting edge mesh programs out there. The latest release works like a champ, you  have to understand mesh networking to know what your getting, but this is fantastic. I hope they get with the HacDC guys and work a mutual exchange between this and byzantium.

title: This is amazing
comment: On a humanitarian level, I'm impressed by the idea of this app: community-driven communication. As an app, it works between 2 devices for both voice and messaging at present (1 rooted / 1 unrooted), although it seems to have minor glitches on the unrooted device (not allowing it to be switched off). I've tried it indoors, but think it could be useful in overseas conference centres, or perhaps on cruise ships, as well as in rural communities. The former 2 may require development of an iphone app for maximal effect though...

title: Exciting
comment: Probably the most exciting app on Play.  The implications are immense.  Im really looking forward to file transfers in a later release.  Keep up the good work and don't let this evaporate.

title: Wish I could have gotten it to work :(
comment: I tried to use to Galaxy S3's but it didn't work. Cut in and out a little when placed back-to-back, but wasn't usable. Perhaps it was something I was doing wrong.

title: Good Stuff
comment: I would have to say that this is good stuff. It works on my Samsung Galaxy Nexus running stock Android 4.1.2 and both of my Motorola Backflip's running cyanogenmod 7.1.0. It works better on my Motorola Backflip's then on my Samsung Galaxy Nexus. The only problem I have is that I have to do a force stop on my Samsung Galaxy Nexus to turn it off and the call gets a little choppy most of the time but it is better then not having any phone service at all. On my Motorola Backflip's it have no problems. If you use The Serval Mesh with Open Garden then we could have a true mesh network. Good job and keep up the good work.

title: Like A Telco Darknet
comment: Pretty cool :) A telco darknet. I was able to use an Evo 4G and a Droid 1 to mesh and make a call between them. However when I introduced a third device (HTC Hero) into the mix all 3 devices didn't want to stay meshed up. Sometimes 2 would stay meshed and the other device wouldn't join up. The best I managed was 2 out of the 3 devices at any given moment. Voice calls were a tad laggy but not horrible in my limited test.
awesome!

title: Welcome to the future!
comment: Decentralized, democratic communications application. I look forward to it's widespread use, and seeing base stations with large antennas to help establish permanent MeshNet networks.

title: Awesome
comment: Does what says on the tin and more.
Great app! Let's all install it and stick it to the networks that keep overcharging us.

title: Very promicing
comment: I've got this working on my i5700 with cyanogenmod and on my stock U8110 and can make calls between the devices. Calls have more echo and lag than is ideal, but are comprehensible. I would love to see more users running this, in the developed world as well as in places with limited infrastructure or disaster areas. This type of totally decentralized technology has the potential to play an extremely significant part in our future.

title: GREAT IDEA

title: Donate button required!
comment: This project is one of the most promising ones I've ever seen! :-P  I can't wait to see the new version; I'd only like the gateway interface to be simpler (or more documented)... and then I'll be able to convert all of my friends to mesh networks! :-P

title: At first, all but bricked my phone
comment: Sorry, bro, but this app has all but bricked my stock Droid 4.  When the app was trying to figure out how to drive the wifi, the phone rebooted and ever since, will crash almost all the programs on my phone, eventually crashing the OS and forcing the phone to reboot.  After a hard reboot, it seemed to be working okay, but is still having issues.  Forced to uninstall it =(  Great idea, just needs wider platform support.

title: An app worthy of praise
comment: The aims of the Serval Mesh project should be supported. Visit the project website for full info. As Android users tend to be more tech-minded, I hope people will try the app and give useful feedback to the devs. For me, I have it on a Hero and a NexusOne, communicating, sort of... :)

title: The concept alone is worth supporting
comment: And if serval does it right, these otherwise useless devices we are putting precious metals into will become a device that truly serves the people.
